And obviously in the business world.
World, it's all about numbers and the motivation for kind of starting data market to kind of give you a little bit of a background was pretty much that.
This is my 4th startup company, so I've written a fair share of business plans in my life.
Also been involved in both decision making and kind of planning for larger organizations and me and my Co founder.
He comes more from the enterprise side.
We found those over and over in the same situation.
We wanted to base our plans or decisions on the best available.
Numerical data out there and it was.
Basically hard to find, understand and you are a couple of things to that.
First of all, you know we, you know the kind of situation that we repeatedly found ourselves in was.
We want we needed some data, some demographics information.
We started out on Google, we would end up with a PowerPoint there in a PDF here in an Excel sheet.
Then some data from proprietary databases and so on.
An even after spending time finding all that data, you still set with this kind of heterogeneous pile of different resources.

On your hard drive that you still have to kind of do quite a lot of work with if you want to kind of draw that comparison chart or work it into your Excel model or whatever it is that you wanted to do with that data and we figured we're probably not the only people in the world having that problem, so wouldn't it be great if there was a solution for that?
Wouldn't there be great if there was almost like a Google phone numbers where you know people in that situation could dive?
And simply kind of look up the best available numbers for Four Thirds.
For the for whatever they need to do so just to quickly.

Very simply, the way data market works that way or technology works is that it lies on top of a lot of different quantitative data sources and data sources like statistics officers, data sources like a lot of data from different public offices.
Also data sources like market research companies and so on and so forth.
All the different kind of numerical databases that you could find and the system is.
Extremely good at kind of taking that.
Putting it all in one place and allowing you to search it.
So if I want to know something, for example about broadband in Ireland.
Broadband.
I simply type it then as I would on Google, it searches through data from the UN World Bank euros, that IMF, some of the local statistics office is here and comes back with 139 results.
And here we see kind of different datasets from different providers and here's one called households with broadband tax.
It comes from euro start its yearly data that goes back to 2003 was actually updated just a week ago or so.
So if I click that instead of taking me off to Eurostar, swept it aside or a third party website.
I actually get the data right there and then.
I have the data set here.
This is kind of the data as euros that lies it out and they want to compare Ireland to Iceland.
I can do so and kind of the data is right there at my fingertips, and this is the way it works.
There's a lot more to it, but I just wanted to kind of tell you what it is we do before I tell you.
Kind of about the journey that we went through with our business.
So essentially, it's.
It's a system that puts a lot of data at your at your fingertips.
So back to the presentation.
So the product that we've created essentially a software as a service solution that brings together relevant data together in one place.

It provides a single user interface that allows you to kind of search, visualize, compare and download this data, essentially putting it there at your fingertips, and it's licensed by two types of organizations.

Data publishers that use our tool not necessary not under kind of our brand, but under their own brand to publish data and then data consumers that use our system to take in data from a lot of different kinds to solve the problem that I originally mentioned, where instead of having to go out to all these different pages and normalizing the data themselves, the system our system does it for them.
So yeah, I'm going to skip skip that one hour status today.
Well, essentially, it's just saying we have a lot of data from a lot of different places, and usually when we set it up for a new customer we will integrate additional data sources to it.
Because, you know, we don't, even though we have a lot of data, we have some 2 1/2 billion fact values in there.
There is always, you know, for every single customer we need there are more space.
If it meets the status of our company today, we're still small where 15 people in three countries.
I myself live in the states now where we're building out of sales and marketing operation and that kind of comes back to the point that was brought up here earlier.
Whereas and we have three people there or development offices are open ice and then we have one guy working out of Scotland.
We have a few $1,000,000 or euros in sales, many hundreds of millions of Icelandic kroner, and it's no longer kind of.
We've kind of passed the survival phase.
It's now a question of growth.
It's kind of a question of how we go from here to being large and profitable organization.
We could essentially just stop where we are, and we'd be in the black.
But getting here has taken some experimentation.
We actually started the company back in 2008 and that's it.
Kind of experiences I'm going to share, so plan number one.
You know the kind of the what we felt was the obvious solution to the problem of kind of people having hard time finding finding data.
What do people use to kind of search today?
They use Google.
Will make a Google phone numbers.
Will make a one kind of 1 size.
Fits all website where everybody can come today to market.com they can type in a keyword query like the one I just did and find the best available data.
Business plan behind that.

The idea was that we would build a user base of 10s of thousands of users that would pay us for two things they would pay for pro licenses that you know essentially be a freemium model where you would get additional features to the system by paying a subscription.
And Secondly we would be reselling data from people that are in the business of creating data.
Market research companies, financial data providers and so on.
Now we found that this had numerous problems.
First of all, we had a pretty, you know, we found it pretty easy to build the user base.

We have 10s of thousands of users that use our system every every month, but especially on the reselling end on getting kind of data from market research companies and so on to resell through our services turned out to be hard.
They typically want to keep their customers close to them, and while they do have affiliate programs with reseller programs for a lot of their qualitative stuff, meaning reportes and so on.
The data products are not necessarily the same, so they were kind of.
There were a few.
There were a few, you know.
I mean, this just didn't fly.
We saw in the numbers a few months after we started this back in January 2011.
We saw that this wasn't going anywhere.
But the interesting thing is that we had built.

We built connections now with market research companies in the market research companies, even though they didn't like our business plan to kind of re sell their data, they really liked our platform and they've been kind of instead of delivering the PDF's in the Excel sheets that they do today, they've been looking for something more engaging and kind of on.
Line and more web 2O E like this to deliver the data for a long time.
We got into discussions with them on licensing their own licensing the platform to allow them to publish the data through our tool, and that's what we've been doing for the past 18 months.
And I mean, this turns out to be a pretty decent business.
We estimate that we can maybe grow to be 1520 million dollar company kind of just focusing on the information industry.

But that still, I mean around the world, there are potential maybe 500 clients in that space, so it's not the huge market that we went after, and it's still not kind of we're not solving the problem that we were kind of set out to solve, so planning.
Three in the one that we've kind of, you know.
So we are still very actively kind of licensing the platform to information providers.

But what we've found now is a far bigger market and kind of where we hit the problem right on target is to build what we call a data hubs for for kind of the strategic and market intelligence organizations within enterprises.
So what we essentially do instead of building A1 size fits all data market.com, which is more like a Google for numbers.
It's actually we sit down with an organization we analyzed where they take the data from.
We make sure all that data is in our system in a setup that is specifically for them, so it allows them to put some of the kind of more proprietary data in there as well and.
Thereby kind of solve the problem because a tool like this has to have the answer 90% of the time.
If it's going to be the tool that you use for this.
Otherwise you kind of go back to Google and we get to that 90% much quicker by doing it kind of on a customer by customer basis than trying to build something very generic so.
Here's a picture of kind of what we're trying to achieve.
The world of Business Intelligence is very much focused on internal data.
Business intelligence systems typically give you like a window on what's happening internally in the company and lie on top of internal databases.
What we're trying to give companies a single window on is the external world.
The world of market intelligence and surveys and trackers, and strategic intelligence looking kind of forward looking external.
I sometimes use the analogy when you're driving a car you spent most of the time looking outside the windshield, not at the task board.
The PA system.
So the dashboards that tell you how much gas you have and kind of how fast you're going, but you'll probably crash pretty soon if you don't look at kind of what's out there, so.
That's what we're trying to kind of give you give give our customers a view on the external bit.
So target.
Customers I've kind of gone briefly through this, so these are kind of as we go down this pyramid.

They're larger organizations that we sell to a higher number for a lower price as we move on, we are essentially still kind of focused very much at the top of this pyramid on the data publishers on the kind of bigger, bigger companies and management consulting firms, but we're kind of with more automation with more development to our system and with more available data in our kind of court databases, will gradually getting down to.
Being almost like you know, more like a Salesforce, you know software as a service solution that people sign up to and they have access to all the market intelligence right there.
So the three lessons I was going to see.
With you and title of the title of the slide that I feel we have learned from this journey is the same technology can be many different products.
It's a question of how you shrink wrap it, who you sell it to, how you price it, and so on.

We haven't changed course with our technology development once during our journey, but we've changed the kind of the all the innovation except for kind of the problems that really need to kind of the technical problems that we needed to solve all the innovation has been on the business side.
Lesson #2 fail fast fail often is bullshit, so this is kind of the mantra these days kind of throw throw money at it.
Throw people at it for six months and kind of see what sticks.
This doesn't build lasting, lasting businesses.

If we'd done that, if we'd kind of raised money to kind of go after the original idea, we have developed valuable technology, we'd have crashed in those six months with left it, and we'd be doing something completely different.
So value lost.
And lesson #3 And this is one of my favorite quotes.
It's actually a quote.
Then the sweetest Alpine skier Ingemar Stenmark.
The more you practice, the luckier you get.
And what I'm trying to get at with that is that it's always a random walk.

You know, there is almost a lot of randomness and luck involved in kind of building a business, but you have to kind of recognize the what was the phrase from from Blackadder, the cunning plan or the singing?
Dancing naked and on the piano you kind of have to recognize it when it when it's there and you know there by the more you practice, the luckier you get, meaning that you you become you.
You start to kind of recognize the opportunities as they open up.
So those are my kind of three lessons from changing or pivoting our business plan overtime and developing our business.
And yeah, that's the conclusion of that.
